sentences: Colin John Loughnan (pronunciation ; born 26 October 1942) is an Australian jazz saxophonist, teacher, and composer, best known as a member of the Delltones, Ayers Rock, Judy Bailey quartet, and as a teacher of saxophone at the Sydney Conservatorium of Music.

Although Loughnan has long been associated with jazz music, the first nine years of his career were spent as a non-instrumental vocalist with vocal harmony groups The Crescents, and The Delltones starting in 1958.
He was playing with Kala in London in 1973, before returning to Australia to join progressive rock, jazz fusion outfit Ayers Rock.
He flew back to Australia in 1978 to take up the position of lecturer in saxophone, and arranging at the Sydney Conservatorium of Music Jazz Faculty.
Another collaborator, guitarist Steve Murphy joined Loughnan to record the album Feel the Breeze as a duo in 1981.
Loughnan toured with Georgie Fame and The Aussie Blue Flames on Fame's frequent visits to Australia from 1979 to 2006.
Loughnan recorded a solo album Ellen St., in 2007, of his own compositions, which was produced by his son, bassist Lyal Loughnan, and Loughnan himself.
Colin John Loughnan was born on 26 October 1942, in Sydney, and became a professional musician, arranger, and teacher of saxophone.
From 1957, he studied at South Sydney Junior Technical High School (now known as South Sydney High School), after which he was employed as an apprentice fitter and turner.
The 4 Tops were regular performers, in late 1958, at the Leichhardt Police Boys Club dances, run by Johnny O'Keefe (no relation to Dennis O'Keefe).
O'Keefe invited The Crescents to appear on his television program "Six O'Clock Rock" on 7 March 1959.
Gordon also drafted The Crescents into his "Big Shows": The Johnnie Ray Show in August 1959, and Fabian in October the same year.
In October 1959, Leedon released their first single, "Everlovin'" backed with "You Broke My Heart", the latter being co-written by Loughnan and O'Keefe, but it failed to chart.
Their next record, "When You Wish upon a Star" was released in April 1960.
O'Keefe crashed his expensive imported red Plymouth near Kempsey in June 1960, suffering severe head, and facial injuries, and spending a fortnight in hospital.
In November 1960, Loughnan, Alan Heffernan, Barry Stanton, and Ray Hoff were rounding a bend on a Victorian road, when a tyre blew out.
The Crescents were invited to perform at The Ricky Nelson Show in September 1960.
By June 1961, The Crescents had released another three singles, and two EPs, without any chart success.
Even so, they continued working for another year until Noel Widerberg of the Delltones died in a car accident on 7 July 1962.
Loughnan was invited to become vocal harmony group, the Delltones, new lead singer in September 1962.
In November 1962, they cut a new single "Come a Little Bit Closer" by Leiber and Stoller, which became the Delltones biggest hit, making it to No. 1 in Sydney.
The surf music inspired "Hangin' Five" by Ben Acton was also a big hit in November 1963.
From 1965, Loughnan was privately learning to play the saxophone at home in Randwick.
One of the five concerts in Vietnam was at Bien Hoa Air Base on 1 March 1966 in stifling heat.
Loughnan married Rhonda Moore on 30 May 1966.
In 1967, Loughnan decided to take a very different direction, and left the Delltones after five years as a member.
By October 1967, Loughnan had joined the band, not as a vocalist, but as a saxophonist.
In early 1968, Loughnan's services were no longer required because The Soulmates were cut back to a four piece outfit.

In 1968 Loughnan joined Col Nolan & The Soul Syndicate, a jazz combo with Col Nolan on organ and piano, John Allan on electric bass, Loughnan playing saxophone and flute, and multi-instrumentalist John Sangster on drums.

sentences: In October 1973, Loughnan was invited to join a recently formed band, Ayers Rock, by his friend, and former bandmate Doyle.
By December 1973 Ayers Rock had signed with Mushroom Records, and Mushroom co-owner, Michael Gudinski, was their manager.
Jimmy Doyle, 1975
The album, Big Red Rock, was released in Australia and New Zealand in November 1974.
In December 1974, Gudinski flew to the US with "a stack of Mushroom records" to promote his artists to record company executives, with Ayers Rock the only successful band.
The North American release of Big Red Rock went ahead on 28 February 1975, and the English release in March.
Ayers Rock left Australia in July 1975 on their first tour of the US, also including one gig across the Canada–US border in Vancouver.

sentences: On the album, titled Beyond, which was released in Australia and the US in April 1976, Loughnan wrote the title track, "Beyond", as well as "Place to Go", and "Angel in Disguise".

sentences: Loughnan joined the academic staff at the Sydney Conservatorium of Music, University of Sydney in 1978 as a lecturer in saxophone and arranging.
He has taught at the Conservatorium of Music every year from 1978 to the present.
Feel The Breeze was re-released on CD in 2004 by La Brava Music (LB0060).
In the early 1980s, he studied under venerated saxophone teacher Joe Allard in New York City.
His long-term collaboration with Judy Bailey has extended from the late 1970s to the present.

Although Loughnan has long been associated with jazz music, the first nine years of his career were spent as a non-instrumental vocalist with vocal harmony groups The Crescents, and The Delltones starting in 1958.

Ayers Rock put a proposal to Gudinski that they could record the album live-in-the-studio in two days.
This was attractive to Gudinski because at that moment his company, Mushroom Records, was critically short of funds.
The sessions at Armstrong's (21—22 September 1974) were described as "having a party before an audience with lights, drinks and food".
